rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence is less than 20,000 km², it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which does not appear to be under threat, has a presumed large population, and is unlikely to be declining at nearly the rate required to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
habitat: H. intectus is apparently terrestrial and nocturnal. It is known to inhabit both primary cloud forest and adjacent secondary growth, usually in cool and very humid environments (Gómez-Laverde et al. 2015).
threats: In the northern part of its range deforestation is prevalent (C. Delgado pers. comm.).
population: This species appear to be abundant (or at least easily trapped) at most places where it has been found to date (Voss et al. 2002).
range: This species is restricted to Cordillera Central of the central Andes of Columbia between 1,700 m and 2,800 m elevation. It is known in the departments of Antioquia, Quindío, and Risaralda (Gómez-Laverde et al. 2015).
conservationActions: This species is found in several reserves, but not national parks.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, occurrence in a number of protected areas, and because it is unlikely to be declining at nearly the rate required to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
habitat: This rodent is poorly known. It is restricted to moist humid cloud forest and co-occurs with the larger Thomasomys hylophilus, which it resembles (Aagaard 1982). It is terrestrial, omnivorous, and nocturnal.
threats: No major threats, although deforestation is affecting the species in some parts of its range.
population: In Ecuador this rodent is uncommon (Tirira in prep.). In Venezuela it is rare (Linares 1998).
range: This species occurs in the north Andes, from central Ecuador (Musser et al. 1998), through central and north Colombia, to west Venezuela (Handley 1976, Linares 1998, Musser and Carleton 2005). It has an altitudinal range of 1,100 to 3,700 m.
conservationActions: This species occurs in a number of protected areas throughout its range. Further research is needed to determinate its taxonomic status.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining at nearly the rate required to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
habitat: It has been found in dense forest (Voss et al. 2002). This mouse is terrestrial, and mostly diurnal and crepuscular. It probably feeds on insects, seeds, and vegetation (Quiceno 1993).
threats: There are no major threats to this species.
population: This species is common, especially in secondary and altered areas (R. Anderson and M. Gómez-Laverde pers. comm.). Voss et al. (2002) captured 10 specimens of this species in the valley of the Rio Siato, Departamento Risaralda, Municipio Pueblo Rico, Vereda Siato, at 1,520-1,620 m, with 405 trap-nights.
range: This species occurs in the Cordillera Occidental of western Colombia (Musser and Carleton 2005); it also occurs in the Cordillera Central, Colombia (Gómez-Laverde pers. comm.). It has an altitudinal range of 1,300 to 3,000 m (Alberico et al. 2000).
conservationActions: This species occurs in Farallones de Cali, Tatamá, Las Orquideas in the Cordillera Occidental, and in Los Nevados National Parks and other protected areas.

rationale: Ilex colombiana es una especie arbórea que está presente en Colombia, Ecuador y Bolivia. La especie cuenta hasta el momento con 15 subpoblaciones conocidas y presenta una distribución geográfica amplia. La mayoría de las subpoblaciones de la especie se encuentran en hábitats poco perturbados por actividades humanas, y algunas ocurrencias están al interior de áreas de protegidas. No se conocen amenazas que puedan poner en peligro la especie, por lo que se considera de Preocupación Menor.
habitat: La especie ocurre en hábitats de bosques de tierras altas (elevación mayor a 1.000 m snm). La especie es probablemente polinizada por insectos y dispersada por aves (Dolce y Medina 2017).
threats: La mayoría de las subpoblaciones de la especie se encuentran en hábitats poco perturbados por actividades humanas.
population: La especie tiene registradas hasta el momento 15 subpoblaciones. No se conoce nada sobre la abundancia o tendencia poblacional de la especie.
range: La especie está presente en Colombia, Ecuador y Bolivia. Se registra en región Andes.
useTrade: No se han reportado usos para la especie.
conservationActions: La especie está presente en áreas protegidas de Latinoamérica. No se conocen otras acciones de conservación para la especie.

rationale: Axonopus scoparius has been assessed as Least Concern due to its large range across Southern America and its weedy nature (Global Compendium of Weeds) and lack of direct threats.
habitat: This species is found in moist/dry/montane/flooded forest and alpine/montane/flooded grassland ecoregions. It is found along the Andes mountain range suggesting its preference for high altitudes. It also prefers well-drained, fertile soils with high organic matter content, but will also grow on acid, less fertile soils. It is well adapted to the moist, sub-humid to humid tropics, not very drought tolerant and grows well in a fairly wide temperature range (14-26°C). It is rather similar to the closely related micay grass (Axonopus micay García-Barr.). The latter can be distinguished by its non-tufted, creeping, rhizomatous habit, shorter growth (thus used for grazing), much shorter central rachis of the panicle and lower number of spikelets/spike.
threats: There are major threats to the ecoregions in which this species resides including fragmentation due to deforestation for cultivation of crops such as coffee, oil/gas prospecting, cattle ranching and increased human settlement. However, these threats are not known as yet to directly affect this species.
population: The exact population size is not known, however it is thought this species is common due to its listing in the Global Compendium of Weeds.
range: This species is distributed along the Andes mountain range in South America, and also the Galapagos Islands and Costa Rica.
useTrade: No information available.
conservationActions: This species is found in several protected areas including national parks and reserves.

rationale: Despite its small extent of occurrence, this species is listed as Least Concern because it is common and its entire distribution is within a protected area with no major threats affecting it.
habitat: Malpelo Island is a rocky island with lower forms of plant life such as algae, mosses, and lichens on vertical rock faces moist with fresh water and under ledges (Wolda 1975). This scansorial species eats ants, crickets, and presumably flies, obtained between the cracks and small caves on the island and  human buildings (Huey 1975, López-Victoria 2006).
threats: It is unlikely that this species has major threats as its entire range is within a protected area.
population: Population size was estimated between 30,000 to 60,000 individuals (Lopez-Victoria 2006), although these estimations may be too high due to the methodology employed.
range: This species is endemic to Colombia; where it is known only from Malpelo Island (Huey 1975, López-Victoria 2006). It occurs at elevations between sea level and 300 m asl.
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: The species occurs in Malpelo Island, which is a national park.

rationale: Lepidoblepharis colombianus has been assessed as Data Deficient on the basis that, while its known extent of occurrence is below 20,000 km2, there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, and the population is suspected to be severely fragmented, the latter requires confirmation and ongoing taxonomic research may reveal that this species is more widespread, potentially extending into areas where it is at lower risk and possibly with an extent of occurrence in excess of 20,000 km2. On this basis it is presently unclear whether this species warrants listing as Vulnerable or whether instead it should be listed as Least Concern, and further research is needed before an accurate assessment of the conservation status of L. colombianus can be carried out.
habitat: This species is found in montane dry forest habitat. It has very specific microhabitat requirements, as it relies on situations with high humidity and leaf litter cover and does not persist in disturbed habitats (M. Calderon pers. comm. 2016).
threats: Much of the original forest cover has been removed from this heavily populated region, and what patches remain are highly fragmented. Feral goats, which were introduced in the 1500s, are further degrading the remaining patches of natural habitat in this area.
population: There is no population information available for this species. Given its highly specific habitat requirements and the patchy distribution of remnant suitable habitat within its range, it is suspected to occur as a severely fragmented population (M. Calderon pers. comm. 2016).
range: This species is known from 'temperate climate elevations' on the western slopes of the Cordillera Oriental, state of Cundinamarca, Colombia. The type was recorded at 1,600 metres. The area in which this species is distributed is approximately 14,651 km²<sup></sup>. The species may however be more widespread, as preliminary evidence from taxonomic research on populations towards the Piedemonte and Amazonia suggests that these may be referable to this species (G. Medina, pers. comm. to M. Calderon).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. A taxonomic reevaluation of this species is needed. Better information is needed on current distribution, abundance, trend, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen and nothing is known of its distribution, population status, ecological requirements or its sensitivity to possible threats from agricultural development in this region of Colombia.
habitat: From its elevational distribution it can be inferred that this fossorial species is found in lower montane tropical forest.
threats: There is intensive agriculture, including coffee plantations, in this region of Colombia, which has a high human population density. It is unknown whether these represent likely threats to this species, as some fossorial species adapt well to disturbance and essentially nothing is known of the ecology of this species.
population: This species is known only from the holotype, collected in 1946 (Kofron 1988, Santos 2018). As a fossorial species, it is likely to be naturally difficult to detect.
range: This species is known only from its type locality in La Selva, Pueblo Rico, Department of Risaralda (formerly in the Department of Caldas), Colombia, at an elevation of 1,700 m asl. (Marx 1953, Peters and Donoso-Barros 1986).
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species, which is known only from one specimen.
conservationActions: Surveys of the type locality are required in an effort to rediscover this species.

rationale: Colombian Weasel is listed as Vulnerable under C2a(i), inferring a population size of at least 1,350 mature individuals from the current known range and a plausible population density, and assuming a continuing decline in population due to ongoing deforestation (acknowledging the species may potentially tolerate some level of forest degradation). The range is sufficiently extensive to make it highly likely that no one subpopulation holds over 1,000 mature individuals. In addition, it is plausible that the species might meet the threshold for Vulnerable under D1 (a total population of 1,000 mature individuals or fewer) if the density is only three-quarters of the arbitrary figure given in the 'Population' section (and again assuming that the current range is not larger). This listing may be slightly evidentiary. Indeed, a categorisation of Endangered under C2a(i) is not out of the question, especially as no subpopulation may hold more than 250 mature individuals; however, equally, the total population size might also be severely underestimated, especially if the range is larger than currently documented (implying a larger population than speculated here). On balance, it is unlikely that this species's the true range has been fully documented so far, especially for a species so difficult to identify by typical mammal survey methods. Hence, Vulnerable seems to be a more appropriate listing, pending re-assessment when more information becomes available.
habitat: Almost nothing is known of Colombian Weasel's habitat preferences (Schreiber et al. 1989), but its naked foot soles with extensive interdigital webbing and records in areas of riparian habitats suggest that the species is adapted to water-edge environments (Ramírez-Chaves & Patterson 2014). The few specimens have been obtained from between 1,525 and 2,700 m, an altitude range where cloud forests predominate.
threats: Colombian Weasel occurs in a limited geographic area where deforestation is rampant (Nowak 2005, Etter and van Wyngaarden 2000); a significant proportion of the estimated range of the species has been deforested for agriculture and illicit crops. Between 1990 and 2010, forest cover net loss within the species´s known extent of occurrence (EOO) reached 10% overall, and was 13% within its suitable habitat (areas within its EOO) between 1,500 and 2,700 m a.s.l.); for the last potential distribution model for the species (Ramírez-Chaves and Mantilla-Meluk 2009) a net forest loss of 26% was estimated for the period of 1990-2010. Forest lost estimates before 1990 indicate even a larger net loss (Etter and van Wyngaarden 2000). Currently, there is only 36% of forest cover within the EOO, 35% within the altitudinally suitable EEO, and 25% within the last modelled distribution. These deforestation trends are likely to continue given the historical drivers still operating in the area. The extent of the species's association with forest is, however, unknown, so the relationship of these deforestation statistics to the species's population trend is also unclear. For example, the former could overestimate the latter if the species is not particularly tied to forest, or if densities are higher in degraded and edge areas than in pristine forest; or they could be an underestimate if the species is tied to a particularly rapidly declining microhabitat.
population:
No information regarding population size, density or trend is known for the species. Recent efforts to record the species in six potential localities within its range (two near two previously known localities) failed to detect it (Ramírez-Chaves and Patterson 2014). At the other three of the five known localities, natural habitat was severely transformed and fragmented.

Schreiber et al. (1989) noted that it is among the least-recorded carnivores in South America, and assumed this likely to reflect a genuine great rarity. Considering the species is difficult to identify even in the hand, it was suggested that it might be more represented in collections than previously thought; however, a recent review of most collections with mammal specimens from this species's range corroborated the rarity of the species in collections (Ramírez-Chaves et al. 2012). The rarity of sight and other non-specimen records cannot be taken as evidence of the species's abundance: it cannot, on current knowledge, be safely identified except in the hand. Without this ability to generate sight records, it will remain a labour-intensive challenge to determine the species's status: the perceived distribution and conservation status of two forest weasels of Indochina, Stripe-backed Weasel M. strigidorsa and Yellow-bellied Weasel M. kathiah, have been completely changed by birders' sight-records, often photographically documented, backed up by road-kills in areas where tourist roads have penetrated montane forest and bring in large numbers of nature-aware tourists (Abramov et al. 2008, Supparatvikorn et al. 2012). For these two latter species, and a third South-east Asian congener, Malay Weasel M. nudipes, examination of recording patterns in areas where multiple methods are used show that camera-trapping is very poor at detecting them, and even when these species are recorded by formal survey or research activities, it is usually incidentally outside the structured methodology; a remarkable number of records come from observers taking mid-day baths in forest streams (Duckworth et al. 2006, Abramov et al. 2008, Supparatvikorn et al. 2012). Such options are greatly reduced for Colombian Weasel: road-kills and animals retained by villagers (perhaps killed in retribution for perceived livestock losses) are the only plausible modes of generating incidental records where the confident identification to species can be upheld.

The area of suitable habitat (as the extent of natural habitat remaining within the known Extent of Occurrence, and within the altitude band of 1,500-2,700 m a.s.l., within which all records lie) was assessed as about 5,600 km² (J.F. González-Maya pers. comm. 2015). A density of one full-grown animal per 2.8 km² sounds credible for a forest weasel for which all evidence suggests the high likelihood of living at low densities: this would give 2,000 animals. Assuming about two-thirds of the population comprises mature individuals, the total global number of mature individuals would be about 1,350. The range is sufficiently extensive to make it highly likely that no one subpopulation holds over 1,000 mature individuals.
range:
Only six specimens of Colombian Weasel, from five localities in four provinces or departments, have been obtained: from western Colombia (departments of Chocó-Valle del Cauca, Huila and Cauca) and northern Ecuador (province of Napo). The most northern is from 4°51'N, and the most southern from 0°25'N. Recent re-examination of Neotropical  Mustela  specimens in many collections revealed no new M. felipei, re-affirming the conventional view of the rarity of the species; many published accounts contain records in error or for which the reliability cannot be judged (Rámirez-Chaves et al. 2012). It is however possible that the species has been under-recorded because, in this part of the Andes, weasels in general are extremely challenging to identify in the field: this species is morphologically very similar to Long-tailed Weasel M. frenata (Rámirez-Chaves et al. 2012).

Tirira and Gonzalez-Maya (2009) traced records from 1,525 to 2,700 m a.s.l.; a record from a lower altitude was considered to be an error of identification by Rámirez-Chaves et al. (2012).
conservationActions: One specimen was collected in Cueva de los Guacharos National Park (Ramírez-Chaves et al. 2012). Purace National Park is also close to a collecting site (Schreiber et al. 1989). In Ecuador the species has not been recorded in any protected area (Tirira and González-Maya 2009). Potentially, according to models, the species could be potentially present in 10 protected areas in Colombia (Ramírez-Chaves and Mantilla-Meluk 2009, Burneo et al. 2009) and 14 in Ecuador (Burneo et al. 2009); but no confirmed records exist from any of these areas (Ramírez-Chaves et al. 2012). Determining the conservation needs is hampered by the minimal information on the species's natural history. It is therefore a high priority to find and study an extant population, particularly its habitat use and threats (if any). At least five field efforts in six localities in Colombia (two adjacent to previous records) failed to detect the species (Ramírez-Chaves and Patterson 2014, J.F. González-Maya pers. comm. 2015). Moreover, natural habitat at three of the five known localities have been severely fragmented in recent years.

rationale: This western central Atlantic species is known from Isla de Providencia (Colombia) and Venezuela. It has no major threats. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is demersal.
threats: There are no known threats for this species.
population: There is no species specific population information available.
range: This western central Atlantic species is known in the Caribbean Sea from Isla de Providencia (Colombia) and along the coast from the Gulf of Morrosquillo, Colombia to Carupano, Venezuela (Acero 1984).
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements, and threats.
habitat: The holotype was recorded during the night on the leaf of a species of the genus Puya ("achupalla") in sub-Andean forest, a few meters from a ravine with rocky outcrops, and about 50 cm above the ground (Ruiz-Carranza et al. 1986). The larvae presumably develop in streams like other species of the genus, but the site of egg deposition is not known.
threats: Within the region where this species occurs, water pollution from agriculture and human disturbance from the planting of illegal crops are considered to be a problem. However, further field work is needed to determine how these threats could be affecting this species, especially with relation to any potential population declines.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, which is known only from one specimen (an adult female).
range: This species is known only from the type locality: Inza municipality in Cauca Department, on the eastern slope of the Cordillera Central of the Colombian Andes, at 3,030 m asl (Ruiz-Carranza et al. 1986). It presumably occurs more widely, but this requires confirmation.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The type locality is within Parque Nacional Natural Puracé.

Research Needed
Studies on its population size, distribution and trends, life history and ecology, and threats are needed.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats and its presumed large population.
habitat: It lives in open grasslands and savannahs, often in relatively dry areas. The species uses ephemeral or permanent small pools for breeding, but can also be found far from the water. At the onset of the first rains, these frogs emerge from sandy soils where they hide during the dry season. They make foam nests in water. It is an adaptable species and occurs in some modified habitats.
threats: There are no major threats; it is a widespread, adaptable species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining.
population: It is a very common species and the population is thought to be stable and with no known significant threat.
range: This species ranges from Guyana and northern Brazil (Roraima State), through Venezuela (including Isla Margarita) and eastern and northern Colombia into the Pacific lowlands of Panama from Azuero to central Panama. It is also native in Aruba, but introduced in Curaçao, Klein Bonaire and Bonaire, and recently established on St. Martin/St. Maarten (Janse et al. 2020). Its range does not reach French Guyana (cf. Lescure and Marty 2000), and currently there are no records from Suriname. It possibly also occurs in Amazonas State, Brazil. It occurs up to 500 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: It has been recorded in several protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
habitat: This nocturnal and burrowing species inhabits lowland dry forests to premontane rain/wet forests (Jaramillo et al. 2010). It is associated with lentic water bodies, such as temporary and permanent ponds, where it breeds after the rains. Males usually call from the ground and partially submerged vegetation. Eggs are laid in water bodies, where tadpoles develop (Jaramillo et al. 2010). During the dry season, it probably lives inside termite mounds (Renjifo and Lundberg 1999, Cuentas Montalvo et al. 2002). Ants make up the largest proportion of the diet of these frogs, while beetles, termites, spiders, and mites are consumed to a lesser extent (Blanco-Torres et al. 2015, Atencia-Gándara et al. 2017). Individuals were found in secondary habitats such as plantations (Angarita-M. et al. 2015), suggesting at least a degree of tolerance to habitat degradation. It is sympatric with Phyllomedusa venusta and Scarthyla vigilans in Venezuela and northern Colombia.
threats: Some subpopulations are presumably affected by ongoing habitat loss due to coal mining in northern Colombia and Venezuela, and, to a lesser extent, by agriculture and livestock farming (Cuentas Montalvo et al. 2002, Blanco-Torres et al. 2015, T. Barros pers. comm).
population: This species was considered to be frequently observed and protected globally (Young et al. 1999), while in Panama, it seems to be rare (21-100 observations). In a temporary pond in northern Colombia, 13 specimens were collected in a survey effort of 30 minutes (Cuentas Montalvo et al. 2002). Likewise, Angarita-M. et al. (2015) considered this species as “very rare” in the agroforestry systems of Colombia because the relative abundance index was lower than 0.25. Very little information is available regarding its status in the Maracaibo Lake basin in Venezuela, where it appears to be uncommon. According to Tito Barros pers. comm., individuals can be observed in Venezuela when males call during and following heavy rains.
range: This species occurs mainly in the western Pacific of Panama, the Caribbean lowlands and inter-Andean valley of Magdalena in Colombia, and extends eastwards to northwestern Venezuela, comprising almost the entire Maracaibo Lake basin, including the foothill of northern Serrania de Perijá. It is a low and middle-elevation species (Young et al. 1999, Infante et al. 2006, Acosta Galvis 2019), which ranges between sea level and 750 m asl.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being used by humans or in trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Measures In-Place
This species occurs in several protected areas such as Parque Nacional Cerro Hoya in Panama (Flores et al. 2017), and national parks Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta and Paramillo in Colombia (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020).

Research Needed
Due to the scarcity of information on the taxonomy and natural history of this species, further research should be focused on its life history and ecology, as well as to understand the relationship  between the subpopulations from Venezuela and Colombia compared to those from Panama, and the cis-Andean populations of Elachistocleis from northern South America.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and its presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits humid lowland forest, living in leaf-litter. It is not found in degraded habitats, but it can tolerate slight disturbance. It breeds by direct development and is not dependent upon water.
threats: The major threats are deforestation for agricultural development, illegal crops, logging and human settlements, and pollution resulting from the spraying of illegal crops.
population: It is slightly more common than the sympatric species Oedipina complex. The species has been extirpated at El Copé, Panama (Crawford et al. 2010). There is no recent information from Colombia. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs in central Panama in the Pacific and Atlantic lowlands and cordilleras, and in the eastern cordilleras adjacent to central Panama, extending into the Choco region and the Lower Cauca Valley in Antioquia Department of northwestern Colombia. It is found below 700 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: This species occurs in the following protected areas: Cerro Campana National Park; Soberania National Park; Chagres National Park; Isla Barro del Colorado National Monument; and is close to Utria Natural National Park in Colombia.

rationale: The information available is not adequate to assess the conservation status of the species and it is therefore classed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species occurs in lagoons and montane rivulets (Anon. 2014).
threats: There are no known significant past, ongoing or future threats to this species.
population: There is no information available on population trends in this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Colombian Andes, with records from Magdalena, Tolima and Boyaca Departments (Anon. 2014).
useTrade: This species is not believed to be used or traded.
conservationActions: This species is not represented in protected areas. There is an urgent need to survey and document populations, to enable an assessment of its conservation status.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because is widely distributed and there are no major threats affecting it, and also occurs in at least one protected area.
habitat: This pelagic fish it has been found in rivers and creeks.
threats: This species could be affected by habitat modification and pollution produced by urbanization.
population: There are no data on population size and/or trends, but seems to be stable.
range: This species is endemic to the Magdalena River Basin in Colombia (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2008), where it has been found in the Fonce River (San Gil municipality), Santander (type locality) (Eigenmann et al. 1914), Nevado River in the Chicamocha river system (Capitanejo municipality), Frío River (Floridablanca municipality), Manco and Chicamocha rivers (Piedecuesta municipality), La Naranjera ravine, a tributary of the Playón river, Lebrija river system (Playón municipality) (Castellanos-Morales et al. 2011). In the last years this species was found in the Santa Marta, Sierra Nevada  (Minca and Dibuya Rivers). This species occurs between 700 to 1,500 m asl.
useTrade: This species does not appear to be used or traded.
conservationActions: This species occurs into the Sierra Nevada National Park. There are no direct conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: Bunocephalus colombianus is listed as Data Deficient as it is a cryptic species that is only very rarely caught. No information is therefore available on its population size or status, or the threats that are affecting it.
habitat: It inhabits the bottom of rivers and creeks, feeding on small worms and other soft animals (Dahl 1971, Maldonado et al. 2005).
threats: The threats to this species are not known. However, it may be highly sensitive to disturbances of river beds, such as dredging for mining.
population: No data are available on population size or trends. It is a cryptic species that is only rarely caught.
range: This species is endemic to Colombia where it occurs in the Magdalena-Cauca basin, and in the Caribbean and Chocó basins (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2008). Its type locality is Boca de Raspadura (Eigenmann 1912).
useTrade: The species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in Parque Nacional de Los Katíos. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trends and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: Although this species has a restricted distribution, is present in a protected area and there appears to be no known major threats affecting it. Therefore it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: It has been found in ravines with clear waters and sandy bottom with riparian vegetation (Ardila-Rodriguez 2008).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Caribbean drainage in Colombia (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2008), particularly in the Upper Sinú River basin (Netto-Ferreira et al. 2011). Its type locality is Quebrada El Higuerón, a tributary of the Sinú River in Tierralta, Department of Córdoba (Ardila Rodríguez 2008).
useTrade: The species is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species is present in the Parque Nacional Natural Paramillo (Netto-Ferreira et al. 2011).

rationale: This species is considered Least Concern, as it can be locally common, occurs in at least two protected areas, and known threats are not widespread throughout its range. However, the record from the Santander department in the Oriental Cordillera is only based on one museum specimen, and is therefore doubtful, and if this record proves incorrect then the threats may be more severe than currently thought.
habitat: This highland species has been found close to forest habitats in wooded areas close to lakes (Bota-Sierra 2014).
threats: Mining for gold and logging for urban expansion may pose a threat at some localities.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species. However, the populations are considered numerous and conspicuous (Bota-Sierra 2014).
range: This species is endemic to Colombia where it occurs in the northern portion of the Central and Oriental Cordilleras in the departments of Antioquia and Santander, between 2,400 and 3,270 m (Bota-Sierra 2014). The presence in the Santander Department needs confirmation though.
useTrade: This species is not believed to be used or traded in any way.
conservationActions: This species occurs in the Belmira Páramo Complex and El Romeral protected areas. It is not known whether any further conservation measures are required, although a survey of the Santander region to verify this species' presence is highly recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
habitat: This species is associated with premontane and montane forests, cloud forests and secondary forests. It is found in the forest interiors (Cubides and Cardona 2011), although it is also found on low vegetation and is very common in roadside forests, especially juvenile individuals. It breeds by direct development.
threats: Agriculture, both crops and livestock, as well as the fumigation of crops is a major threat to the species’ habitat.
population: It is relatively abundant where it has been recorded, and the population is considered to be stable.
range: This species is known from the eastern and western slopes of the Cordillera Occidental, and the eastern and western slopes north of the Cordillera Central in the departments of Antioquia, Caldas, Quindio, Risaralda and Valle del Cauca. It has been recorded from 980–2,600 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Its range includes several protected areas.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because the population is suspected to be declining at a rate of at least 80% over a 10 year period (2015–2025) due to intensive illegal trade, human consumption, and habitat loss due to deforestation for agricultural development, logging, mining activities, the introduction of predator species and the effects of climate change on the water bodies which this species is dependent for its reproduction.
habitat: This species lives in closed-canopy tropical lowland and premontane rainforest, often found in riparian areas along streams. It has been found in natural forests with little human intervention. Breeding takes place in temporary and permanent pools, sometimes close to rivers (where metamorphs in particular are often found). Females are able to produce thousands of eggs per season (Castro-Herrera and Bolívar-G 2010).
threats: Major threats includes habitat loss and degradation due to agricultural development and cultivation of illegal crops, logging, mining activities, the introduction of exotic species such as tilapia, as well as, agricultural and domestic pollution. In southern Colombia it is affected by illegal mining activities that overlaps about a third of its distribution in the country. In northern Ecuador, expanding oil palm plantations is a major driver of habitat loss (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2021). The species may be affected by climate change because it depends on puddles for reproduction and many of these bodies of water have dried up in places where the species was once common (D. Mejía pers. comm. 2016).
population: In Ecuador, this species can be locally common where good forest cover remains, but it declines rapidly once the habitat is lost or becomes too degraded (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2021). In Colombia, it is a rare species. The species is acoustically conspicuous, but has not been recorded in recent surveys throughout its range in recent years (D. Mejía and W. Bolívar pers. comm. 2016). Considering the high rate of habitat loss throughout much of this species' range, as well as, predation by introduced taxa and ongoing decline in mature individuals due to harvesting of this species from the wild, the population is suspected to be declining at a rate of more than 80% over a 10 year period, from 2015–2025.
range: This species occurs in northern Ecuador (in Esmeraldas, Imbabura and Carchi Provinces), and in Colombia (Nariño, Cauca and Valle del Cauca Departments), on the western flank of the Cordillera Occidental. It occurs at elevations ranging from 200–1,050 m asl.
useTrade: This species is collected from the wild and commercially exported for pharmacological research and for the pet trade. It is also under additional pressure because it is collected and consumed by local communities. It is thought that these collective activities heavily affect the population (D. Mejía pers. comm. 2016).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Although there are no records in protected areas of the state, its existence is presumed in the Reserva Ecológica Cotacachi Cayapas in Ecuador. It has been recorded in a few protected areas in Colombia. Ex-situ management programmes have been partially successful, as animals collected in the field have been reproduced in various zoos around the world. However, and despite the fact that it adapts well to captivity, only first generation descendants have been produced (Coloma and Hoogmoed 2014).

Conservation Needed
Habitat restoration and protection of suitable habitat is recommended for this species. Legislation is needed to regulate the international trade and the harvesting of this species. 

Research Needed
Further research in population trends, ecology and distribution are recommended for the species.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 732 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in four threat-based locations and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of habitat due to the expansion of cattle ranching activities.
habitat: This species occurs in oak forest patches immersed in a matrix of cattle farms, and has not been recorded from anthropogenic habitats. It breeds by direct development.
threats: The main threat is habitat loss due to agricultural expansion, especially expanding pastures for cattle grazing. Climate change was previously reported to be a threat in the 2004 assessment, however this has not yet been supported by any studies and the effect of this remains unknown on the species.
population: It is a common species within its relatively small range.
range: This species is known from the type locality, "El Chaquiro in Antioquia Department, Colombia" (amended to "Hacienda Palmas, El Chaquiro in Antioquia Department, Colombia, at 2,670 m elevation"), and from the municipalities of Belmira, San José de la Montaña and Santa Rosa de Osos. Its EOO is 732 km2 and it occurs in four threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species has not been recorded in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection remains the most urgent conservation action required. 

Research Needed
Further survey work is needed to determine the extent of its distribution.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
habitat: This nocturnal, terrestrial species inhabits montane and premontane wet forest, scrub vegetation on Andean piedmont and disturbed secondary forest, and leaf litter of gallery forest and isolated woodland forests (Heyer 1994, Angarita-Sierra 2014, Pedroza-Banda et al. 2014, Restrepo et al. 2017). Specimens have been observed hidden under the roots of aquatic plants, or in holes at the edges of water bodies. Males construct foam nests, on which the females lay the eggs. Tadpoles develop in streams. It feeds on invertebrates (Palacio Baena et al. 2006, Galvis Peñuela et al. 2011).
threats: This taxon is not facing major significant threats. It is tolerant to disturbed or transformed habitats such as oil palm plantations (T. Angarita-Sierra pers. obs.). In Colombia, habitat transformation due to agriculture, cattle grazing, urbanization, mining, and to a lesser degree, the construction of large-scale infrastructures, such as hydroelectric dam projects (Galvis Peñuela 2011, Angarita-Sierra 2014, Restrepo et al. 2017) could pose potential threat. The premontane and montane forest habitats where this taxon occurs have the highest rate of deforestation in the Venezuelan Andes (Bisbal 1988). Chytridiomycosis is a potential threat, as it has been widely recorded in localities of the Venezuelan Andes (Lampo et al. 2008).
population: In Colombia, it seems to be locally common. It was last collected in Colombia in 2016-2017 (Ovalle-Pacheco et al. 2019). The single series known in Venezuela was collected in 1995.
range: This taxon is widely distributed throughout the Colombian lowlands, with disjunct populations in the Caribbean region and transAndean Magdalena and Cauca River Basins, and the eastern foothills of the Cordillera Oriental and Orinoquian savannas. Its distribution corresponds to the transitional environments towards the flatlands known as Llanos, with few records in the Caribbean drainage, between 300 and 2,300 m asl (Heyer 1994, Acosta Galvis and de Sá 2018, Acosta Galvis 2019). In Venezuela, it is only known from a single series collected at Río Doradas, 28 km south of Pregonero in Táchira State, at 630 m asl (Barrio-Amorós and Chacón 2001), close to the Colombian border (Norte de Santander Department), which requires verification (De Sá et al. 2014).
useTrade: The "llaneros" or peasants who live in the flooded savannas of the Pauto River in Casanare, Colombia, use this frog as bait for fishing (T. Angarita-Sierra pers. obs.).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in several protected areas such as the Tinigua, and Páramo de Tamá, natural/national parks, the Montes de Oca, and Guajira forest reserves, and Las Jaguas, and San Carlos private protected areas, both located in Antioquia Department (Restrepo et al. 2017).

Research Needed
Research on the taxonomic relationship between the different subpopulations, mainly those that inhabit the inter-Andean valley areas, is required. Studies of ecology and life history are also recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
habitat: This species lives in disturbed areas, such as pasturelands that formerly supported cloud forest, and has not been found in closed forest (Bolívar et al. 2011, Cubides and Cardona 2011). It is typically associated with open areas, especially where there are still waterbodies, such as small lakes, reservoirs, grassy marshes or pools, and natural and artificial wetlands. Some specimens have been found the introduced plant Zantedeschia aethiopica (Díaz-Ayala et al. 2014). It breeds in permanent and temporary ponds (Cubides and Cardona 2011).
threats: It is very adaptable and not significantly threatened, except possibly by water pollution resulting from aerial spraying.
population: It is a common species and the population is considered to be stable. One hundred nine individuals were collected for a diet study from six collection sites (farms) in the department of Quindío from 2006 to 2007 (Moreno-Barbosa and Hoyos-Hoyos 2014). Between 2009 and 2015 at least one individual was found at each of 10 different urban forest remnants in the city of Armenia in the Quindío department (Vanegas-Guerrero et al. 2016).
range: This species from the Colombian Andes occurs on the western slopes of the Cordillera Central and eastern and western slopes of the Cordillera Occidental (in the Departments of Cauca, Quindío, Risaralda, and Valle del Cauca) at 950–2,300 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is not known from any protected areas.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its area of occupancy (AOO) is 8 km<sup>2</sup>, its distribution is severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat on the Eastern Cordillera of the Colombian Andes resulting in an ongoing decline in the number of threat-defined locations.
habitat: This species lives in streams in cloud forest, but only in old growth forest. The eggs are laid on vegetation and the tadpoles larvae in streams.
threats: Habitat loss due to agriculture and cattle ranching, and predation by introduced trout are the major threats to this species. At the type locality, habitat loss is also occurring due to the ongoing highway project.
population: This species was common, but recent surveys report a drastic decreasing of individuals in type locality due to highway projects. There are no records of it since 2010 (M. Rivera-Correa pers. comm. August 2016). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs on the western slope of the Cordillera Oriental in the department of Santander, Colombia, between 1,900–2,700 m asl. It may be more widely distributed than existing records indicate. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 106 km<sup>2</sup> and its AOO is estimated to be 8 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species has not been recorded in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
There is an urgent need for expanded protection of remaining forest habitats in the Colombian Andes.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements, and threats.
habitat: It calls from beneath leaf-litter and from holes in the ground covered with leaf-litter in humid tropical forest. The eggs and larvae develop in small, temporary rain pools.
threats: The threats to the species are unknown. It may be threatened by habitat loss due to illegal mining and cultivation of illegal crops, and by pollution resulting from the spraying of illegal crops; however, this requires confirmation.
population: It is thought to be rare, but it is a secretive forest species so this has not been confirmed. The population status is uncertain.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Quebrada Guanguí, in the upper Río Saija drainage, in the department of Cauca, Colombia, from 100-200 m asl. It is most likely a wider ranging species, but more sampling is needed to confirm this.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The type locality is not within a protected area.

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur. 

Research Needed
Studies on its population size, distribution and trends, life history and ecology, and threats are needed.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It inhabits savannahs, dry forests, and riparian forests in open, dry environments. It probably also occurs in shrubland, grassland, and artificial habitats such as pastureland. No information is available on breeding, but like other species in the genus it presumably takes place in water.
threats: It is considered an aggressive species, which is not facing any known threats.
population: It is very common in Colombia. Subpopulations in Venezuela are probably also stable (C. Señaris pers. comm. 2020).
range: This species is widely distributed in the Lower and Middle Magdalena Valley in northern Colombia. It has also been recorded from a site in the Maracaibo Lake basin in Venezuela, an area that is lacking recent herpetological exploration work (C. Señaris pers. comm. 2020). It ranges from sea level up to 150 m asl.
useTrade: This taxon does not have any known use or trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Measures In-Place
It is likely to occur in protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020), although no information is available.

Research needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status and ecology.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because its distribution, abundance, trend, and threats are too poorly known to allow the species to be placed in another category.
habitat: There is little information on the habitat and ecology of this species. However, like other members of its genus, it is probably associated with streams and waterfalls in montane forest. The eggs are carried on the back of the female, where they develop directly without a larval stage.
threats: There is no information about threats affecting the species. However, the region where this species occurs has been severely affected by mining for salt production, and all possible suitable remaining habitat for this taxon has been destroyed at the type locality. But there is suitable habitat north and south of the type locality (J. Carvajal-Cogollo pers. comm. March 2017).
population: This species is only known from the holotype that was collected in the 1940s. Surveys prior to 2004 in the region of the type locality did not produced any individuals. There have been no surveys between 2004 and this reassessment at the type locality, due to ongoing armed conflict which has recently ceased in the area. There are plans to visit the type locality and near areas in the second half of 2017 (J. Carvajal-Cogollo and F.L. Meza-Joya pers. comm. March 2017).
range: This species is known only from the type locality of La Salina, Casanare Department, Colombia, at 1,450 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 75 km2.

conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species has not been recorded in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Conservation recommendations are pending following future surveys and once the population status of the species and habitat requirements are determined (F.L. Meza-Joya pers. comm. March 2017).

Research Needed
Additional survey work is urgently required to determine whether or not it still survives in the wild. More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Further taxonomic research is also needed to ascertain the true genus that it should be assigned to [either Hyloscirtus or Cryptobatrachus] (J. Carvajal-Cogollo pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the species is known from only a single specimen; its full range, natural history, and threats are unknown.
habitat: Habitat presumably is lowland tropical rainforest.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats exist to this species.
population: This species is represented by a single specimen.
range: This species is known only from the type locality: Leticia, Colombia.
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: Conservation needs include better information on the species' distribution, abundance, life history, population trend, and threats.

rationale: This species occurs in a restricted area (extent of occurrence is <5,000 km<sup>2</sup>) and, while well-represented in museum collections, it is restricted to forest habitat which is severely fragmented both by human activity and naturally by elevation. Deforestation at elevations where the lizard occurs is ongoing, and although pressure is currently relatively low its range lies close to the major city of Manizales. It is consequently listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species has been found in high montane forest, and beneath cover objects such as logs in open areas outside the forest, including areas close to human habitation (J.C. Arredondo pers. comm. 2013, Sánchez-Pacheco 2010).
threats: The high montane forest this species prefers is fragmented, and while it can occur in open areas it is absent from open habitats without nearby forest. It does, however, occur in remote areas where tracts of largely pristine cloud forest survive. Deforestation is ongoing, perhaps for cattle ranching, but the elevations where this species occurs are too high for intensive human use. Nevertheless, areas where this species occurs are impacted by forest clearance and its range lies close to the major city Manizales.
population: Three specimens were recently collected from an isolated locality in montane forest in a single day, suggesting that this is a common species (C. Arredondo pers. comm. 2013). It is known from many specimens in museum collections (Sanchez-Pacheco 2010).
range: Riama columbiana occurs at moderate elevations (from 2,100 m to 2,640 m asl.) on the western slope of the Cordillera Central, Colombian Andes, in the departments of Caldas, Risaralda and Quindío, and probably Antioquia (Arredondo and Sánchez-Pacheco 2010, Sánchez-Pacheco 2010).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species has been found close to Los Nevados Natural National Park.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered due to its tiny range (known only from the type locality), ongoing threats (tourist damage to the habitat), and lack of observations since 1964 despite extensive herpetological survey work in the vicinity of the type locality. Research is needed to determine if this species is still extant.
habitat: This terrestrial leaf litter species is found in semiarid coastal forest (Lamar 1985).
threats: Presumably tourism is a threat because the type locality receives heavy visitation by tourists visiting the nearby beaches. The failure to record this species in a well-surveyed area for more than 50 years raises questions as to whether the species still exists.
population: This species was collected only on one day in August 1964, when seven individuals were collected. This area is widely visited by herpetologists collecting geckos, but no one has collected the species since 1964. The type locality is a popular beach.
range: Lepidoblepharis miyatai is known only from its type locality in the Caribbean coast of Department of Magdalena, Colombia. All the specimens were collected near sea level (Lamar 1985).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: This species occurs within the Parque Nacional Natural Tayrona. However, this park attracts numerous tourists visiting the beaches, and this could degrade the lizard's habitat. Conservation needs include taxonomic research, and further surveys to determine whether a population survives and, if so, its full distribution and population trends.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient, as it has not been recorded since 1980 and occurs in an area of difficult access where, despite the existence of a national park, there may be threats. The apparent extent of occurrence is small, so the species may be threatened, however, it is unclear whether this species is truly restricted to this area, and if so whether it is particularly sensitive to threats from illegal land clearance.
habitat: This species occurs in wet montane forest with decaying logs.
threats: It occurs within a protected  area where illicit crops can threaten forest-dependent species, but it is unknown whether this species is particularly sensitive to this pressure.
population: Little is known about the population of this species. It was last collected in 1980.
range: This species is known from the mountains of Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, and Rio Frio, both located in the Department of Magdalena, Colombia. The holotype from Santa Marta Mountains was collected at an elevation of 5,000 feet (1,524 metres) (Huey and Dixon 1970, Avila-Pires and Hoogmoed 2000).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in  the Parque Nacional Natural Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Research is needed to understand this species' distribution and population status.

rationale: This species has a very small range, and it is thought to be dependent on oak forest habitats that are severely fragmented and declining in area and quality. Therefore the species is classified as Endangered.
habitat: It inhabits subtropical and temperate forests at elevations of 1,900-3,100 m (Ridgely and Tudor 1989, Fjeldså and Krabbe 1990, Jaramillo and Burke 1999, Renjifo et al. 2002, Fraga and Sharpe 2016, T. Donegan in litt. 2012). Studies in the Cordillera Oriental have revealed that it has strongly specialised habitat requirements, being limited to humid oak (Quercus humboltii) forests (Cortes-Herrera and Hernandez-Jaramillo 2007). It is particularly abundant in forest and at forest edge near marshes, and the interface between forests and wetland areas appears to be an important habitat for the species (Fundación ProAves de Colombia 2011). Observations are invariably of small groups in the middle and upper strata, and breeding-condition birds have been collected in September (Ridgely and Tudor 1989, Fjeldså and Krabbe 1990, Jaramillo and Burke 1999). The species breeds co-operatively (Cadena et al. 2002, Fraga and Sharpe 2016), with colonies generally being located in either Quercus humboltii or Escallonia pendula trees (Cortes-Herrera and Hernandez-Jaramillo 2007) and a breeding season from May-September (Fraga and Sharpe 2016). It associates with mixed species frugivore flocks, and has been recorded in flocks of up to 30 individuals in the Yariguíes mountains (T. Donegan in litt.2006).
threats: Since the 17th century, the west slope of the East Andes has been extensively logged, burned and cleared for conversion to agriculture (Stiles et al. 1999). This species's dependence on oaks Quercus humboltii make it highly susceptible to the effects of logging, cutting for firewood and grazing by cattle, which is thought to limit oak forest to marginal relict patches on steep and rocky areas (Cortes-Herrera and Hernandez-Jaramillo 2007). However, in some areas above 2,500 m, forest cover remains more extensive (Stiles et al. 1999). Landscape changes accelerated during the 20th century, especially after 1960, although in some areas habitat regeneration is beginning following the abandonment of marginal land (Stiles et al. 1999). Deforestation is also taking place for mining operations, principally gold mining (O. Cortes in litt. 2011). Pastures dominate the valley below Guanentá-Alto Río Fonce, but the forest is mostly intact from 1,950-2,200 m upwards. However, the lower tracts are still affected by selective logging. Landslides, following the loosening of soils after deforestation, present a threat to relict patches of forest on slopes (Cortes-Herrera and Hernandez-Jaramillo 2007).
population: Given that the species is apparently abundant at some sites and a minimum conservative estimate of 800 individuals has been provided for the Yariguíes population (Fundación ProAves de Colombia 2011; although it has been suggested that it could be as low as 150-200, O. Cortes-Herrera in litt. 2012), it is likely that the total population lies between 1,000 and 2,499 individuals. This equates to 667-1,666 mature individuals, rounded here to 600-1,700 mature individuals.
range: Macroagelaius subalaris occurs mainly along the west slope of the East Andes in Colombia. There are historical records from south-west Cundinamarca, north to the tip of the East Andes in Norte de Santander, where it also occurred on the west slope south to the upper Zulia valley (M. Alvarez and P. G. W. Salaman in litt. 1999), and it may have occurred throughout the east slope. However, the only recent records are from Guanentá-Alto Río Fonce Fauna and Flora Sanctuary, Santander, where it has been described as common (D. Uribe per L. M. Renjifo in litt. 1994) and Serranía de los Yariguíes (Donegan et al. 2007). Its range has certainly contracted following complete deforestation in some areas. Surveys recorded the species in 22 localities (including one from which the species was historically known) from La Aguadita in Cundinamarca to Surata in Santander (Velásquez-Tibatá et al. 2005), although follow-up surveys found that many of these sites are being rapidly deforested and the species may have suffered local extinctions (O. Cortes in litt. 2007, 2011, 2012). In surveys of Serranía de los Yariguíes between 2003 and 2006, the species was recorded from three sites. At one of those sites, it was abundant; at the others it was observed less frequently (T. Donegan in litt. 2006, Donegan et al. 2007). Surveys in Yariguíes revealed high abundance in forest bordering a wetland, which may constitute an important habitat for the species (Fundación ProAves de Colombia 2011). The Yariguíes mountains probably harbour a population of at least 800 individuals, and they are regarded as the core area for the remaining global population (Fundación ProAves de Colombia 2011, Fraga and Sharpe 2016).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
In Colombia, formerly considered Critically Endangered (Renjifo et al. 2002), but now assessed as Endangered at the national level (Renjifo et al. 2014). Guanentá-Alto Río Fonce Fauna and Flora Sanctuary protects 100 km2 of forest at 2,200-3,900 m. The highest elevations of Serranía de los Yariguíes National Park remain largely inaccessible and fall within the new national park boundaries. Reserva Páramo La Floresta probably harbours at least 100 individuals (Fundación ProAves de Colombia 2011). Also reported from Las Orquídeas, Cueva de los Guácharos and Tatamá National Parks, and from Ucumarí Regional Park (Fraga and Sharpe 2016). This species's ecology is being studied in Soatá (Cortes-Herrera and Hernandez-Jaramillo 2007).

Conservation Actions Proposed
Ascertain the status of birds and habitat throughout its former range, especially areas that have not been visited recently. Conduct studies to determine whether the species is dependent on oak forest throughout its range (Cortes-Herrera and Hernandez-Jaramillo 2007). Increase the area of suitable habitat that has protected status. Search for the species in other areas containing marshes adjacent to forest (Fundación ProAves de Colombia 2011).

rationale: The Colombian Dwarf Numbfish (Diplobatis colombiensis) is a small (to at least 17 cm total length) ray that is endemic to Colombia in the Western Central Atlantic. It is benthic on the inner continental shelf at depths of 30–107 m. It is captured in intense and largely unmanaged commercial and artisanal demersal trawl fisheries throughout its limited geographic range. This genus only has some refuge at depth in Colombia, where trawling is restricted to shallow inshore waters, and much of this species' range occurs in this country. Due to the level of fishing pressure this species is exposed to across much of its range, offset by its small size and suspected relatively productive life history, it is suspected that the Colombian Dwarf Numbfish has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generations (13.5 years), and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Colombian Dwarf Numbfish is benthic on the inner continental shelf at depths of 30–107 m (Last et al. 2016, García 2017). It reaches a maximum size of at least 17 cm total length. Little else is known of its biology. Generation length is suspected to be about 4.5 years, based on data available for the related Cortez Numbfish (Narcine entemedor), which has a larger maximum size of 75 cm TL, an age-at-maturity of 6 years, a maximum age of 15 years, and thus a generation length of 10.5 years (Villavicencio-Garayzar 2000).
threats: The Colombian Dwarf Numbfish is captured in commercial and artisanal demersal trawl fisheries, which are intense and largely unmanaged across its limited range. In Colombia, industrial shrimp trawling in shallow coastal waters (operating at ~20–40 m depth) began off the Caribbean coast in the mid-1960s and expanded until the 1980s when overfishing became apparent (Wielgus et al. 2010). This species is among the most commonly caught batoids in this fishery (Acevedo et al. 2007), and in the mid-2000s the fishery had one of the highest ratios of bycatch relative to target species of any in the world (Duarte et al. 2010). In Venezuela, commercial and artisanal fisheries are intense, unmanaged, and have exhibited the peaks in catches followed by declines indicative of sequential overfishing (Mendoza 2015). Industrial trawling for shrimp and demersal species was introduced there in the 1940s and increased rapidly from the 1960s until the 1980s when there were 450 registered vessels (Mendoza 2015). Fishing intensity increased for several decades and shrimp landings peaked at ~9,000 t in the 1990s (Manickchand-Heileman et al. 2004). Efforts to address over-exploitation and conflicts with artisanal fisheries led to a reduction to 260 vessels in 2006, and an industrial trawl ban went into effect in 2009 (Mendoza 2015). Reported and reconstructed landings in Venezuela increased substantially from the 1960s until the early 2000s, followed by severe declines in the years since (Mendoza 2015). Since the 2009 industrial trawl ban, artisanal trawl fleets have expanded substantially, with little management and no monitoring in place. Overall, this numbfish is subjected to intense trawling pressure across its range. There is likely to be some refuge at depth in Colombia, where trawling is restricted to shallow inshore waters.
population: Due to the level of inadequately managed fishing pressure that this species is exposed to  across much of its range, offset by its small size and likely relatively  productive life history, it is suspected that the Colombian Dwarf  Numbfish has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past  three generations (13.5 years).
range: The Colombian Dwarf Numbfish is endemic to Colombia in the Western Central Atlantic where it occurs from the Gulf of Urabá to the Guajira Peninsula (Last et al. 2016, Caldas 2017). This species is likely to be confused with and possibly even hybridizes with its congeners the Venezuelan Dwarf Numbfish (Diplobatis guamachensis) and the Painted Dwarf Numbfish (Diplobatis picta), and therefore their ranges should be confirmed.
useTrade: This species is not known to be utilized or traded. Other members of this genus are typically discarded when caught in trawls (Acevedo et al. 2007), and this species is likely to be treated similarly.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in  place for this numbfish. <span class="tlid-translation translation" lang="en">A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is inadequate. Management and mitigation of bycatch is needed in  order to ensure this species does not become more threatened in the near  future. Further research is needed on distribution, life history and population size and  trends, and species-specific monitoring is needed in both  commercial and artisanal fisheries.

rationale: Mimosa colombiana is a shrub or liana and occurs in Colombia and Venezuela. The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is at least 405,000 km2, exceeding the values needed for a threatened category. It is inferred from the availability of suitable habitat that the area of occupancy also exceeds the values needed for a threatened category. The species is found in a variety of habitats and no specific threats are known. It is found in two protected areas. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is a shrub, subshrub or liana (Bernal et al. 2018). It has been collected from a variety of habitats, mainly river banks but also margins of forests, open areas on hills, fields and roadsides.
threats: This species is found in many habitats and specific threats are difficult to identify. Many herbarium specimens have been collected by the Orinoco river where there is cattle ranching and crop cultivation (Moreno et al. 2016).
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: Mimosa colombiana occurs in Colombia (Antioquia, Boyacá, Caqueta, Guaviare, Meta, Quindio, Santander, Valle de Cauca and Vichada departments) and Venezuela (Amazonas, Apure and Táchira states) (BIEN 2018, Bernal et al. 2018). The elevational range from herbarium specimens is 60–1,650 m.
useTrade: There is no information available on the uses of this species.
conservationActions: This species occurs in El Tuparro Nature Reserve and Serrania de las Quinchas Natural Regional Park in Colombia (IUCN and UNEP 2018).

rationale: This species is endemic to the Vaupés region of Colombia. There are only four collections of this species and little is known about the population. There is not enough information about threats, distribution or trends of this species to assess the conservation status of this species. It is here assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Tovomita colombiana can reach up to 15 m tall. The species is endemic to the Vaupés region and occurs in lowland forest between 150–275 m asl along the watercourses, in sand/sedimentary soil (Marinho 2018).
threats: There is no information available on threats to this species.
population: There is no information about the population sizes of this species.
range: This species is endemic to Colombia and found only in the Vaupés region. The species is only known from four collections.
useTrade: There is no information on use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: Only four specimens are known. There is no information about the occurrence of the species in protected areas. There are no ex situ collections of this species (BGCI 2018).

rationale: La especie se categorizó como de Preocupación Menor (LC) porque si bien tiene pequeñas áreas de extensión de presencia (EOO = 908 km<sup>2</sup>), presenta subpoblaciones grandes bien conservadas en áreas bajo protección, sin amenazas significativas.
habitat: Esta especie ocurre en ambiente de páramos.
threats: No se reportan amenazas específicas para la especie.

range: Esta especie es endémica de Colombia, donde se encuentra distribuida en  la Cordillera Oriental en los departamentos de Boyacá y Arauca. La  extensión de presencia fue estimada en 908 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: La especie no es usada ni comercializada.
conservationActions: La especie está bien conservadas en áreas bajo protección, como el Parque Nacional Natural Cocuy y el Parque Nacional Natural Pisba.

rationale: Esta especie está ampliamente distribuida en los Andes de Venezuela y el noreste de Colombia, es común y se encuentra en varias áreas protegidas a lo largo de su distribución. Por lo tanto, se considera como Menor Preocupación (LC).
habitat: Es común en los bosques Andinos de Venezuela y también se suele encontrar en áreas más expuestas como matorrales, cimas y crestas de montañas y es un colonizador agresivo de bosques Andinos recientemente abiertos por deforestación o fuego (Mavarez 2019). En Colombia, esta especie ocurre en matorrales de bosque altoandino húmedo, formando pequeños rodales en laderas escarpadas, normalmente rodeados por cultivos (García et al. 2005).
threats: No hay amenazas significativas para la especie. En Colombia estaría afectada por el avance de la frontera agrícola (García et al. 2005, Morales et al. 2007, Diazgranados et al. 2018).
population: Es una especie muy común en las bosques altos de los Andes Venezolanos e inclusive puede llegar a ser la especie dominante en la línea de bosques (Mavarez 2019). En los sitios de ocurrencia de Pamplona y cuenca del río Chitagá, es menos frecuente y se estima que las subpoblaciones han presentado un decrecimiento debido a la disminución de la calidad y fragmentación del hábitat. La subpoblación del Parque Nacional Natural Tamá se infiere podría ser abundante.
range:
Libanothamnus neriifolius es una especie que se encuentra ampliamente distribuida en Venezuela, y el noreste de Colombia. En Venezuela se encuentra en toda la Cordillera de Mérida y también en las partes altas de la Cordillera de la Costa, entre 1.800 y 3.300 m snm (Mavarez 2019). En Colombia, se conoce de los departamentos de Santander y Norte de Santander, entre 2.000 y 3.250 m snm, alrededor de los páramos Cornejo, Carbón, Tamá, Tierranegra y Fontibón (García et al. 2005, Diazgranados 2012, Cuatrecasas 2013, Diazgranados et al. 2018).

La extensión de presencia (EOO) fue calculada en 69.514 km2 (mínimo polígono convexo alrededor del rango de distribución).
useTrade: Esta especie tiene uso maderable (Diazgranados et al. 2018).
conservationActions: La especie ha sido categorizada como En Peligro (EN) en la Lista Roja Nacional Colombia (2005). Esta presente en varias áreas protegidas a lo largo de su distribución.

rationale: Esta especie tiene una distribución restringida en la cordillera Oriental de Colombia (EOO = 10.557  km<sup>2</sup>) y se encuentra en 10 localidades definidas por amenazas. Hay una disminución continua en la calidad y extensión del hábitat debido a la expansión de los agroecosistemas ganaderos y de cultivos, lo que ha deteriorado las coberturas vegetales naturales en gran parte de las localidades donde se ha registrado, incluso en las que se encuentran en áreas protegidas. Por lo tanto, se lista como Vulnerable (VU).
habitat:
Este arbusto achaparrado puede llegar a medir hasta de 50 cm de alto. Habita en áreas de páramo (Cuatrecasas 1943).

Hay una disminución continua en la calidad y extensión del hábitat debido a la expansión de los agroecosistemas ganaderos y de cultivos.
threats: La principal amenaza para la especie es la degradación y pérdida del hábitat debido a la expansión de los agroecosistemas ganaderos y de cultivos que han deteriorado las coberturas vegetales naturales en 6 de las 10 localidades donde se ha registrado, incluso en las que se encuentran en áreas protegidas.
population: No hay datos de población ni tendencia poblacional para esta especie. Para todos los sitios de ocurrencia se desconoce el número total de individuos maduros e inmaduros presentes.

Linochilus colombianus es una especie endémica de Colombia, conocida de la cordillera Oriental desde el departamento de Boyacá hasta el departamento Norte de Santander, en los complejos de páramos Almorzadero, Guantiva-La Rusia, Iguaque-Merchán, Jurisdicciones-Santurbán-Berlín, Pisba y Sierra Nevada del Cocuy, entre 3.300-4.500 m Asl (Cuatrecasas 1943, Bernal et al. 2015, ICESI and IAvH 2018).

La extensión de presencia (EOO) fue calculada en 10.557 km2, el área de ocupación (AOO) fue calculada en 44 km2 y se identificaron 10 localidades definidas por las amenazas que están afectando a la especie.
useTrade: Se desconoce si la especie es usada o comercializada.
conservationActions:
Actualmente, no hay medidas de conservación para esta especie. Se encuentra en cuatro áreas protegidas: Parque Natural Nacional El Cocuy, Parque Natural Nacional Pisba, Santuario de Fauna y Flora Guanenta Alto Rio Fonce y Parque Natural Regional Pan de Azúcar El Consuelo.

Se recomienda evaluar el estado de las subpoblaciones que se conocen de la especie, explorar otras zonas en los complejos de páramos donde se ha registrado para tratar de ubicar otras subpoblaciones, incluirla como objeto de conservación en los planes de manejo de las áreas protegidas donde ocurre y fortalecer las medidas de protección en estas áreas.

Jalcophila colombiana es una especie endémica de Colombia, conocida por unos pocos especímenes recolectados en el complejo de páramo La Cocha-Patascoy, jurisdicción de los departamentos de Nariño y Putumayo, entre 2.800-4.000 m Asl (Díaz-Piedrahita and Vélez-Nauer 1994, Bernal et al. 2015, ICESI and IAVH 2018). 

El área de ocupación (AOO) fue calculada en 8 km2 y se identificaron 2 localidades definidas por las amenazas que están afectando a la especie.
useTrade: Se desconoce si la especie es usada o comercializada.
conservationActions:
Actualmente, no hay medidas de conservación para esta especie. No se encuentra en áreas protegidas. 

Es necesario identificar y delimitar sitios de conservación para la especie, el adecuado manejo del hábitat donde ocurre y monitorear su población de la especie. Además, se recomienda explorar otras áreas en el complejo de páramos La Cocha-Patascoy para tratar de ubicar otras subpoblaciones, e incluirla como objeto de conservación en el plan de manejo de la Reserva Forestal Protectora Nacional Laguna La Cocha-Cerro Patascoy donde potencialmente puede encontrarse la especie.

rationale: Axinaea colombiana se conoce solamente de diez localidades, que se distribuyen en un área geográfica pequeña (extensión de presencia menor a 3.000 km2). range: La especie es endémica de Colombia, donde se distribuye en la región Andina, en el flanco occidental de la Cordillera Central. Se ha registrado en los departamentos de Caldas, Risaralda, Quindio y Valle del Cauca.

rationale: Esta especie tiene una distribución restringida en la cordillera Oriental de Colombia (AOO = 4 km<sup>2</sup>) y se encuentra en una localidad definida por amenazas). Aunque es probable que se encuentren otras subpoblaciones en el Distrito Regional de Manejo Integrado Páramos de Guantiva y la Rusia, mientras no se tenga más información sobre el estado actual de la población y continúe la transformación de la cobertura vegetal natural en su área de distribución, se debe mantener la categoría de amenaza.
habitat:
Esta hierba terrestre puede llegar a medir hasta 40 cm de alto. Habita en áreas de páramo (Morales 1986).

Sin embargo, la deforestación y la expansión de agroecosistemas ganaderos y de cultivos han disminuido la calidad de su hábitat y constituyen la principal amenaza para la especie.
